sp.l: Alacke alacke Edmund I like not this,
Vnnaturall dealing when I desir'd their leaue
That I might pitty him, they tooke me from me
The vse of mine owne house, charg'd me on paine
Of their displeasure, neither to speake of him,
Intreat for him, nor any way sustaine him.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Most sauage and vnnaturall.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Go toe say you nothing, ther's a diuision betwixt the Dukes,
And a worse matter then that, I haue receiued
A letter this night, tis dangerous to be spoken,
I haue lockt the letter in my closet, these iniuries
The King now beares, will be reuenged home
Ther's part of a power already landed,
We must incline to the King, I will seeke him, and
Priuily releeue him, goe you and maintaine talke
With the Duke, that my charity be not of him
Perceiued, if hee aske for me, I am ill, and gon
To bed, though I die for't, as no lesse is threatned me,
The King my old master must be releeued, there is
Some strange thing toward, Edmund pray you be careful.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: This curtesie forbid thee, shal the Duke instāly know
And of that letter to, this seems a faire deseruing
And must draw me that which my father looses, no lesse
Then all, then yonger rises when the old doe fall.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter, the tyrannie of the open nights too ruffe for nature to indure.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Wilt breake my heart?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I had rather breake mine owne, good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thou think'st tis much, that this tempestious storme
Inuades vs to the skin, so tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is fixt
The lesser is scarce felt, thoud'st shun a Beare,
But if thy flight lay toward the roring sea,
thoud'st meet the beare it'h mouth, when the mind's free
The bodies delicate, this tempest in my mind
Doth from my sences take all feeling else
Saue what beates their filiall ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth should teare this hand
For lifting food to't, but I will punish sure,
No I will weepe no more, in such a night as this!
O Regan, Gonorill, your old kind father
Whose franke heart gaue you all, O that way madnes lies,
Let me shun that, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prethe goe in thy selfe, seeke thy one ease
This tempest will not giue me leaue to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but ile goe in,
Poore naked wretches, where so ere you are
That bide the pelting of this pittiles night,
How shall your house-lesse heads, and vnfed sides,
Your loopt and windowed raggednes defend you
From seasons such as these, O I haue tane
Too little care of this, take physicke pompe,
Expose thy selfe to feele what wretches feele,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And shew the heauens more iust.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Come not in here Nunckle, her's a spirit, helpe me, helpe mee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Giue me thy hand, whose there.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: A spirit, he sayes, his nam's poore Tom.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: What art thou that dost grumble there in the straw, come forth?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Away, the fowle fiend followes me, thorough the sharpe hathorne blowes the cold wind, goe to thy cold bed and warme thee.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Hast thou giuen all to thy two daughters, and art thou come to this?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Who giues any thing to poore Tom, whome the foule Fiende hath led, through fire, and through foord, and whirli-poole, ore bog and quagmire, that has layd kniues vnder his pillow, and halters in his pue, set ratsbane ●y his pottage, made him proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horse ouer foure incht bridges, to course his owne shadow for a traytor, blesse thy fiue wits, Toms a cold, blesse thee from whirle-winds, starre-blusting, and taking, doe poore Tom some charitie, whom
the soule fiend vexes, there could I haue him now, and there, and and there againe.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What, his daughters brought him to this passe, Couldst thou saue nothing, didst thou giue them all?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Nay he reseru'd a blanket, else we had beene all sham'd.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
Hang fated ore mens faults, fall on thy daughters.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: He hath no daughters sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Death traytor, nothing could haue subdued nature
To such a lownes, but his vnkind daughters,
Is it the fashion that discarded fathers,
Should haue thus little mercy on their flesh,
Iudicious punishment twas this flesh
Begot those Pelicane daughters.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Pilicock sate on pelicocks hill, a lo lo lo.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: This cold night will turne vs all to fooles & madmen.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Take heede at'h foule fiend, obay thy parents, keep thy words iustly, sweare not, commit not with mans sworne spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array, Toms a cold,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What hast thou beene?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: A Seruingman, proud in heart and mind, that curld my haire, wore gloues in my cap, serued the lust of my mistris heart, and did the act of darkenes with her, swore as many oaths as I spake words, and broke them in the sweet face of heauen, one that slept in the contriuing of lust, and wakt to doe it, wine loued I deeply, dice deerely, and in woman out paromord the Turke, false of heart, light of eare, bloudie of hand, Hog in sloth, Fox in stealth, Woolfe in greedines,, Dog in madnes, Lyon in pray, let not the creeking of shooes, nor the ruslngs of silkes betray thy poore heart to women keepe thy foote out of brothell, thy hand out of placket, thy pen from lenders booke, and defie the soule fiend, still through the hathorne blowes the cold wind, hay no on ny, Dolphin my boy, my boy, caese let him trot by.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Why thou wert better in thy graue, then to answere with thy vncouered bodie this extremitie of the skies, is man no more, but this consider him well, thou owest the worme no silke, the beast no hide, the sheepe no wooll, the cat no perfume, her's three ons are so phisticated, thou art the thing it selfe, vnaccomodated
man, is no more but such a poore bare forked Animall as thou art, off off you lendings, come on

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Prithe Nunckle be content, this is a naughty night to swim in, now a little fire in a wild field, were like an old leachers heart, a small sparke, all the rest in bodie cold, looke here comes a walking fire.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: This is the foule fiend fliber degibek, hee begins at curphew, and walks till the first cocke, he giues the web, & the pin, squemes the eye, and makes the hare lip, mildewes the white wheate, and hurts the poore creature of earth, swithald footed thrice the old, he met the night mare and her nine fold bid her, O light and her troth plight and arint thee, witch arint thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: How fares your Grace?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Whats hee?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Whose there, what i'st you seeke?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: What are you there? your names?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Poore Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the tode, the tod pole, the wall-newt, and the water, that in the furie of his heart, when the foule fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets, swallowes the old ratt, and the ditch dogge, drinkes the greene mantle of the standing poole, who is whipt from tithing to tithing, and stock-punisht and imprisoned, who hath had three sutes to his backe, sixe shirts to his bodie, horse to ride, and weapon to weare.
But mise and rats, and such small Deere,
Hath beene Toms foode for seuen long yeare.
Beware my follower, peace snulbug, peace thou fiend.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: What hath your Grace no better company?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: The Prince of darkenes is a Gentleman, modo he's caled and ma hu—

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Our flesh and bloud is growne so vild my Lord, that it doth hate what gets it▪

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Poore Toms a cold.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Go in with me, my dutie cannot suffer to obay in all your daughters hard commaunds, though their iniunction be to barre my doores, and let this tyranous night take hold vpon you, yet haue I venter'd to come seeke you out, and bring you where both food and fire is readie.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: First let me talke with this Philosopher,
What is the cause of thunder?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My good Lord take his offer, goe into the house.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ile talke a word with this most learned Theban, what is your studie?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: How to preuent the fiend and to kill vermine.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me aske you one word in priuate.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Importune him to goe my Lord, his wits begin to vnsettle.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Canst thou blame him,
His daughters seeke his death, O that good Kent,
He said it would be thus, poore banisht man,
Thou sayest the King growes mad, ile tell thee friend
I am almost mad my selfe, I had a sonne
Now out-lawed from my bloud, a sought my life
But lately, very late, I lou'd him friend
No father his sonne deerer, true to tell thee,
The greefe hath craz'd my wits,
What a nights this? I doe be seech your Grace.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O crie you mercie noble Philosopher, your com-pany.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Toms a cold.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: In fellow there, in't houell keepe thee warme.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come lets in all.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: This way my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: With him I wil keep stil, with my Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Ken.
sp.l: Good my Lord sooth him, let him take the fellow.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Take him you on.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sirah come on, goe along with vs?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come good Athenian.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: No words, no words, hush.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Child Rowland, to the darke towne come,
His word was still fy fo and fum,
I smell the bloud of a British man.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I will haue my reuenge ere I depart the house.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: How my Lord I may be censured, that nature thus giues way to loyaltie, some thing feares me to thinke of.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
I now perceiue it was not altogether your brothers euill disposition made him seeke his death, but a prouoking merit,
set a worke by a reproueable badnes in himselfe.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to bee iust? this is the letter he spoke of, which approues him an intelligent partie to the aduantages of France, O heauens that his treason were, or not I the detecter.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Goe with me to the Dutches.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: If the matter of this paper be certaine, you haue mighty busines in hand.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: True or false, it hath made thee Earle of Gloster, seeke out where thy father is, that hee may bee readie for our apprehension.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: If I find him comforting the King, it will stuffe his suspition more fully, I will perseuere in my course of loyaltie, though the conflict be sore betweene that and my bloud.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I will lay trust vpon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my loue.
sp.stage: Enter Gloster and Lear, Kent, Foole, and Tom.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Here is better then the open ayre, take it thankfully, I will peece out the comfort with what addition I can, I will not be long from you.

sp.speaker: Ken.
sp.p: All the power of his wits haue giuen way to impatience, the Gods deserue your kindnes.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Fretereto cals me, and tels me Nero is an angler in the lake of darknes, pray innocent beware the foule fiend.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Prithe Nunckle tell me, whether a mad man be a Gentleman or a Yeoman.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: A King a King, to haue a thousand with red burning spits come hiszing in vpon them.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: The foule fiend bites my backe,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: He's mad, that trusts in the tamenes of a Wolfe, a horses health, a boyes loue, or a whores oath.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: It shal be done, I wil arraigne them straight,
Come sit thou here most learned Iustice
Thou sapient sir sit here, no you shee Foxes—

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Looke where he stands and glars, wanst thou eyes, at tral madam come ore the broome Bessy to mee.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Her boat hath a leake, and she must not speake,
Why she dares not come, ouer to thee.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: The foule fiend haunts poore Tom in the voyce of a nigh-tingale,
Hoppedance cries in Toms belly for two white herring,
Croke not blacke Angell, I haue no foode for thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: How doe you sir? stand you not so amazd, will you lie downe and rest vpon the cushings?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Ile see their triall first, bring in their euidence, thou robbed man of Iustice take thy place, & thou his yokefellow of equity, bench by his side, you are ot'h commission, sit you too.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Let vs deale iustly sleepest or wakest thou iolly shepheard, Thy sheepe bee in the corne, and for one blast of thy minik in mouth, thy sheepe shall take no harme, Pur the cat is gray.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Arraigne her first tis Gonoril, I here take my oath before this honorable assembly kickt the poore king her father.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Come hither mistrisse is your name Gonorill.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: She cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Cry you mercy I tooke you for a ioyne stoole.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And heres another whose warpt lookes proclaime,
What store her hart is made an, stop her there,
Armes, armes, sword fire, corruption in the place,
False Iusticer why hast thou lether scape.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Blesse thy fiue wits.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O pity sir, where is the patience now,
That you so oft haue boasted to retaine.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: My teares begin to take his part so much,
Theile maire my counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The little dogs and all
Trey, Blanch, and Sweet hart, see they barke at me.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Tom will throw his head at them, auant you curs, Be thy mouth, or blacke, or white, tooth that poysons if it bite, Mastife, gray hound, mungril, grim-hoūd or spaniel, brach or him, Bobtaile tike, or trūdletaile, Tom will make them weep & waile, For with throwing thus my head, dogs leape the hatch and all are fled, loudla doodla come march to wakes, and faires, and market townes, poore Tom thy horne is dry.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Then let them anotomize Regan, see what breeds about her
Hart is there any cause in nature that makes this hardnes,
You sir, I entertaine you for one of my hundred,
Only I do not like the fashion of your garments youle say,
They are Persian attire, but let them be chang'd.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Now good my Lord lie here awhile.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Make no noise, make no noise, draw the curtains, so, so, so,
Weele go to supper it'h morning, so, so, so,

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Come hither friend, where is the King my maister.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Here sir, but trouble him not his wits are gon.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Good friend I prithy take him in thy armes,
I haue or'e heard a plot of death vpon him,
Ther is a Litter ready lay him in't, & driue towards Douer frend,
Where thou shalt meet both welcome & protection, take vp thy master,
If thou should'st dally halfe an houre, his life with thine
And all that offer to defend him stand in assured losse,
Take vp the King and followe me, that will to some prouision
Giue thee quicke conduct.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Oppressed nature sleepes,
This rest might yet haue balmed thy broken sinewes,
Which if conuenience will not alow stand in hard cure,
Come helpe to beare thy maister, thou must not stay behind.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Come, come away.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: When we our betters see bearing our woes: we scarcely thinke, our miseries, our foes.
Who alone suffers suffers, most it'h mind,
Leauing free things and happy showes behind,
But then the mind much sufferance doth or'e scip,
When griefe hath mates, and bearing fellowship:
How light and portable my paine seemes now,
When that which makes me bend, makes the King bow.
He childed as I fathered, Tom away,
Marke the high noyses and thy selfe bewray,
When false opinion whose wrong thoughts defile thee,
In thy iust proofe repeals and reconciles thee,
What will hap more to night, safe scape the King,
Lurke, lurke.
sp.stage: Enter Cornwall, and Regan, and Gonorill, and Bastard.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Post speedily to my Lord your husband shew him this letter
The army of France is landed, seeke out the vilaine Gloster.

sp.speaker: Regan.
sp.l: Hang him instantly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Plucke out his eyes.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Leaue him to my displeasure, Edmund keep you our sister company.
The reuenge we are bound to take vpon your trayterous father,
Are not fit for your beholding, aduise the Duke where you are going
To a most festuant preparation we are bound to the like,
Our post shall be swift and intelligence betwixt vs,
Farewell deere sister, farewell my Lord of Gloster,
How now whers the King?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: My Lord of Gloster hath conueyd him hence,

Some fiue or sixe and thirtie of his Knights hot questrits after him, met him at gate, who with some other of the Lords dependants are gone with him towards Douer, where they boast to haue well armed friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Get horses for your mistris.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Lord and sister.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Edmund farewell, goe seeke the traytor Gloster.
Pinion him like a theefe, bring him before vs,
Though we may not passe vpon his life
Without the forme of Iustice, yet our power
Shall doe a curtesie to our wrath, which men may blame
But not controule, whose there, the traytor?
sp.stage: Enter Gloster brought in by two or three,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Ingratfull Fox tis hee.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind fast his corkie armes.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What meanes your Graces, good my friends consider,
You are my gests, doe me no foule play friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind him I say,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Hard hard, O filthie traytor!

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Vnmercifull Lady as you are, I am true.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: To this chaire bind him, villaine thou shalt find—

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: By the kind Gods tis most ignobly done, to pluck me by the beard.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: So white and such a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Naughty Ladie, these haires which thou dost rauish from my chin
Will quicken and accuse thee, I am your host.
With robbers hands, my hospitable fauours
You should not ruffell thus, what will you doe.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Come sir, what letters had you late from France?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Be simple answerer, for we know the truth.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: And what confederacy haue you with the tratours late sooted in the kingdome?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: To whose hands you haue sent the lunatick King speake?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: I haue a letter gessingly set downe
Which came from one, that's of a neutrall heart,
And not from one oppos'd.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Cunning.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And false.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Where hast thou sent the King?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: To Douer.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer? wast thou not charg'd at perill—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer? let him first answere that.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: I am tide tot'h stake, and I must stand the course.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer sir?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Because I would not see thy cruell nayles
Pluck out his poore old eyes, nor thy fierce sister
In his aurynted flesh rash borish phangs,
The Sea with such a storme of his lou'd head
In hell blacke night indur'd, would haue layd vp
And quencht the steeled fires, yet poore old heart,
Hee holpt the heauens to rage,
If wolues had at thy gate heard that dearne time
Thou shouldst haue said, good Porter turne the key,
All cruels else subscrib'd but I shall see
The winged vengeance ouertake such children.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Seet shalt thou neuer, fellowes hold the chaire,
Vpon those eyes of thine, Ile set my foote.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: He that will thinke to liue till he be old
Giue me some helpe, O cruell, O ye Gods!

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: One side will mocke another, tother to.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If you see vengeance—

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: Hold your hand my Lord
I haue seru'd euer since I was a child
But better seruice haue I neuer done you, them now to bid you hold.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: How now you dogge.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: If you did weare a beard vpon your chin id'e shake it on this quarrell, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My villaine.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Why then come on, and take the chance of anger.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Giue me thy sword, a pesant stand vp thus.
sp.stage: Shee takes a sword and runs at him behind.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: Oh I am slaine my Lord, yet haue you one eye left to see some mischiefe on him, oh!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Least it see more preuent it, out vild Ielly
Where is thy luster now?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: All darke and comfortles, wher's my sonne Edmund? Edmund vnbridle all the sparks of nature, to quit this horred act.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: Out villaine, thou calst on him that hates thee, it was he that made the ouerture of thy treasons to vs, who is too good to pittie thee.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: O my follies, then Edgar was abus'd,
Kind Gods forgiue me that, and prosper him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: Goe thrust him out at gates, and let him smell his way to Douer, how ist my Lord? how looke you?.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I haue receiu'd a hurt, follow me Ladie,
Turne out that eyles villaine, throw this slaue vpon
The dungell Regan, I bleed apace, vntimely
Comes this hurt, giue me your arme.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: Ile neuer care what wickednes I doe,
If this man come to good.

sp.speaker: 2 Seruant.
sp.p: If she liue long, & in the end meet the old course of death, women will all turne monsters.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Lets follow the old Earle, and get the bedlom
To lead him where he would, his rogish madnes
Allows it selfe to any thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Goe thou, ile fetch some flaxe and whites of egges to apply to his bleeding face, now heauen helpe him.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemnd,
Then still contemn'd and flattered to be worst,
The lowest and most deiected thing of Fortune
Stands still in experience, liues not in feare,
The lamentable change is from the best,
The worst returnes to laughter,
Who's here, my father poorlie, leed, world, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make vs hate thee,
Life would not yeeld to age.
sp.stage: Enter Glost. led by an old man.

sp.speaker: Old man
sp.p:
O my good Lord, I haue beene your tenant, & your
fathers tenant this forescore—

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Away, get thee away, good friend be gon,
Thy comforts can doe me no good at all,
Thee they may hurt.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Alack sir, you cannot see your way.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: I haue no way, and therefore want no eyes,
I stumbled when I saw, full oft tis seene
Our meanes secure vs, and our meare defects
Proue our comodities, ah deere sonne Edgar,
The food of thy abused fathers wrath,
Might I but liue to see thee in my tuch,
Id'e say I had eyes againe.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: How now whos's there?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O Gods, who ist can say I am at the worst,
I am worse then ere I was.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Tis poore mad Tom.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: And worse I may be yet, the worst is not.
As long as we can say, this is the worst.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Fellow where goest?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Is it a begger man?

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Mad man, and begger to.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: A has some reason, else he could not beg,
In the last nights storme I such a fellow saw,
Which made me thinke a man a worme, my sonne
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce friendes with him, I haue heard more since,
As flies are toth' wanton boyes, are we toth' Gods,
They bitt vs for their sport.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: How should this be, bad is the trade that must play the foole to sorrow angring it selfe and others, blesse thee maister.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Is that the naked fellow?

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Then prethee get thee gon, if for my sake
Thou wilt oretake vs here a mile or twaine
Ith' way toward Douer, doe it for ancient loue
And bring some couering for this naked soule
Who Ile intreate to leade me.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Alack sir he is mad.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Tis the times plague, when madmen lead the blind,
Doe as I bid thee, or rather doe thy pleasure,
Aboue the rest, be gon.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Ile bring him the best parrell that I haue Come on't what will.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Sirrah naked fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Poore Toms a cold, I cannot dance it farther.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Come hither fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Blesse thy sweete eyes, they bleed.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Knowst thou the way to Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Both stile and gate, horse-way, and foot-path,
Poore Tom hath beene scard out of his good wits,
Blesse the good man from the foule fiend,
Fiue fiends haue beene in poore Tom at once,
Of lust, as Obidicut, Hobbididence Prince of dumbnes,
Mahu of stealing, Modo of murder, Stiber digebit of
Mobing, & Mobing who since possesses chambermaids
And waiting women, so, blesse thee maister

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Here take this purse, thou whome the heauens plagues.
Haue humbled to all strokes, that I am wretched, makes thee
The happier, heauens deale so still,
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man
That stands your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feele, feele your power quickly,
So distribution should vnder excesse,
And each man haue enough, dost thou know Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I master.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: There is a cliffe whose high & bending head
Lookes firmely in the confined deepe,
Bring me but to the very brimme of it
And ile repaire the misery thou dost beare
With something rich about me,
From that place I shal no leading need.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Giue me thy arme poore Tom shall lead thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord I maruaile our mild husband
Not met vs on the way, now wher's your maister?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Madame within, but neuer man so chang'd, I told him of the army that was landed, he smild at it, I told him you werecoming, his answere was the worse, of Glosters treacherie, and of the loyall seruice of his sonne when I enform'd him, then hee cald me sott, and told me I had turnd the wrong side out, what hee should most desire seemes pleasant to him, what like offensiue.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Then shall you goe no further,
It is the cowish curre of his spirit
That dares not vndertake, hele not feele wrongs
Which tie him to an answere, our wishes on the way
May proue effects, backe Edgar to my brother,
Hasten his musters, and conduct his powers
I must change armes at home, and giue the distaffe
Into my husbands hands, this trusty seruant
Shall passe betweene vs, ere long you are like to heare
If you dare venture in your owne behalfe
A mistresses coward, weare this spare speech,
Decline your head: this kisse if it durst speake
Would stretch thy spirits vp into the ayre,
Conceaue and far you well.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Yours in the ranks of death.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My most deere Gloster, to thee womans seruices are dew
My foote vsurps my body.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: Madam here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I haue beene worth the whistle.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O Gonoril, you are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blowes in your face, I feare your disposition
That nature which contemnes it origin
Cannot be bordered certaine in it selfe,
She that her selfe will sliuer and disbranch
From her materiall sap, perforce must wither,
And come to deadly vse.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: No more, the text is foolish.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Wisedome and goodnes, to the vild seeme vild,
Filths sauor but themselues, what haue you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what haue you perform'd?
A father, and a gracious aged man
Whose reuerence euen the head-lugd beare would lick.
Most barbarous, most degenerate haue you madded,
Could my good brother suffer you to doe it?
A man, a Prince, by him so beniflicted,
If that the heauens doe not their visible spirits
Send quickly downe to tame the vild offences, it will come
Humanly must perforce pray on it selfe like monsters of the deepe.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Milke liuerd man
That bearest a cheeke for blocs, a head for wrongs,
Who hast not in thy browes an eye deseruing thine honour,
From thy suffering, that not know'st fools, do those vilains pitty
Who are punisht ere they haue done their mischiefe,
Wher's thy drum? France spreds his banners in our noystles land,
With plumed helme, thy slayer begin threats
Whil's thou a morall foole sits still and cries
Alack why does he so?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: See thy selfe deuill, proper deformity seemes not in the fiend, so horid as in woman.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O vaine foole!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thou changed, and selfe-couerd thing for shame
Be-monster not thy feature, wer't my fitnes
To let these hands obay my bloud,
They are apt enough to dislecate and teare
Thy flesh and bones, how ere thou art a fiend,
A womans shape doth shield thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Marry your manhood now—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What newes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: O my good Lord the Duke of Cornwals dead, slaine by his seruant, going to put out the other eye of Gloster.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Glosters eyes?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: A seruant that he bred, thrald with remorse,
Oppos'd against the act, bending his sword
To his great maister, who thereat inraged
Flew on him, and amongst them, feld him dead,
But not without that harmefull stroke, which since
Hath pluckt him after.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This shewes you are aboue your Iustices,
That these our nether crimes so speedely can venge.
But O poore Gloster lost he his other eye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Both, both my Lord, this letter Madam craues a speedy answer,
Tis from your sister.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: One way I like this well,
But being widow and my Gloster with her,
May all the building on my fancie plucke,
Vpon my hatefull life, another way the newes is not so tooke,
Ile reade and answer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where was his sonne when they did take his eyes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come with my Lady hither.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No my good Lord I met him backe againe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Knowes he the wickednesse.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I my good Lord twas he informd against him,
And quit the house on purpose that there punishment
Might haue the freer course.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Gloster I liue to thanke thee for the loue thou shewedst the King,
And to reuenge thy eyes, come hither friend,
Tell me what more thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Why the King of Fraunce is so suddenly gone backe, know you no reason.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his comming forth is thought of, which imports to the Kingdome, So much feare and danger that his personall returne was most required and necessarie.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Who hath he left behind him, General.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The Marshall of France Monsier la Far.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Did your letters pierce the queene to any demonstration of griefe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I say she tooke them, read them in my presence,
And now and then an ample teare trild downe
Her delicate cheeke, it seemed she was a queene ouer her passion,
Who most rebell-like, sought to be King ore her.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O then it moued her.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not to a rage, patience and sorow streme,
Who should expresse her goodliest you haue seene,
Sun shine and raine at once, her smiles and teares,
Were like a better way those happie smilets,
That playd on her ripe lip seeme not to know,
What guests were in her eyes which parted thence,
As pearles from diamonds dropt in briefe,
Sorow would be a raritie most beloued,
If all could so become it.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Made she no verball question.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Faith once or twice she heau'd the name of father,
Pantingly forth as if it prest her heart,
Cried sisters, sisters, shame of Ladies sisters:
Kent, father, sisters, what ith storme ith night,
Let pitie not be beleeft there she shooke,
The holy water from her heauenly eyes,
And clamour moystened her, then away she started,
To deale with griefe alone.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: It is the stars, the stars aboue vs gouerne our conditions,
Else one selfe mate and make could not beget,
Such different issues, you spoke not with her since.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Was this before the King returnd.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No, since.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Well sir, the poore distressed Lear's ith towne,
Who some time in his better tune remembers,
What we are come about, and by no meanes will yeeld to see his daughter.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why good sir?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: A soueraigne shame so elbows him his own vnkindnes
That stript her from his benediction turnd her,
To for raine casualties gaue her deare rights,
To his dog-harted daughters, these things sting his mind,
So venomously that burning shame detaines him from Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Alack poore Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Of Albanies and Cornewals powers you heard not.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Tis so they are a foote.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Well sir, ile bring you to our maister Lear,
And leaue you to attend him some deere cause,
Will in concealement wrap me vp awhile,
When I am knowne aright you shall not greeue,
Lending me this acquaintance, I pray you go along with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Alack tis he, why he was met euen now,
As mad as the vent sea singing aloud,
Crownd with ranke femiter and furrow weedes,
With hor-docks, hemlocke, netles, cookow flowers,
Darnell and all the idle weedes that grow,
In our sustayning, corne, a centurie is sent forth,
Search euery acre in the hie growne field,
And bring him to our eye, what can mans wisdome
In the restoring his bereued sence, he that can helpe him
Take all my outward worth.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: There is meanes Madame.
Our foster nurse of nature is repose,
The which he lackes that to prouoke in him,
Are many simples operatiue whose power,
Will close the eye of anguish.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: All blest secrets all you vnpublisht vertues of the earth,
Spring with my teares beaydant and remediat,
In the good mans distresse, seeke, seeke, for him,
Lest his vngouernd rage dissolue the life.
That wants the meanes to lead it.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: News Madam, the Brittish powers are marching hither-ward.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Tis knowne before, our preparation stands,
In expectation of them, ô deere father
It is thy busines that I go about, therfore great France
My mourning and important teares hath pitied,
No blowne ambition doth our armes in sight
But loue, deere loue, and our ag'd fathers right,
Soone may I heare and see him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But are my brothers powers set forth?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: I Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Himselfe in person?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: Madam with much ado, your sister is the better soldier.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lord Edmund spake not with your Lady at home.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: What might import my sisters letters to him?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: I know not Lady.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Faith he is posted hence on serious matter,
It was great ignorance, Glosters eyes being out
To let him liue, where he ariues he moues
All harts against vs, and now I thinke is gone
In pitie of his misery to dispatch his nighted life,
Moreouer to discrie the strength at'h army.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: I must needs after him with my letters

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our troope sets forth to morrow stay with vs,
The wayes are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: I may not Madame, my Lady charg'd my dutie in this busines.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why should she write to Edmund? might not you
Transport her purposes by word, belike
Some thing, I know not what, ile loue thee much,
Let me vnseale the letter.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: Madam I'd e rather—

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I know your Lady does not loue her husband
I am sure of that, and at her late being here
Shee gaue strange aliads, and most speaking lookes
To noble Edmund, I know you are of her bosome.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: I Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I speake in vnderstanding, for I know't,
Therefore I doe aduise you take this note,
My Lord is dead, Edmund and I haue talkt,
And more conuenient is he for my hand
Then for your Ladies, you may gather more
If you doe find him, pray you giue him this,
And when your mistris heares thus much from you
I pray desire her call her wisedome to her, so farewell,
If you doe chance to heare of that blind traytor,
Preferment fals on him that cuts him off.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Would I could meet him Madam, I would shew
What Lady I doe follow.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: When shall we come toth' top of that same hill?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: You do climbe it vpnow, looke how we labour?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Me thinks the ground is euen.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Horrible steepe, harke doe you heare the sea?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: No truly.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why then your other sences grow imperfect
By your eyes anguish.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: So may it be indeed,
Me thinks thy voyce is altered, and thou speakest
With better phrase and matter then thou didst.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Y'ar much deceaued, in nothing am I chang'd
But in my garments.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Me thinks y'ar better spoken.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Come on sir, her's the place, stand still, how feareful
And dizi tis to cast ones eyes so low
The crowes and choghes that wing the midway ayre
Shew scarce so grosse as beetles, halfe way downe
Hangs one that gathers sampire, dreadful trade,
Me thinkes he seemes no bigger then his head,
The fishermen that walke vpon the beach
Appeare like mise, and you tall anchoring barke
Diminisht to her cock, her cock a boui
Almost too small for sight, the murmuring surge
That on the vnnumbred idle peeble chaffes
Cannot be heard, its so hie ile looke no more,
Least my braine turne, and the deficient sight
Topple downe headlong.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Set me where you stand?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Giue me your hand, you are now within a foot
Of th'extreame verge, for all beneath the Moone
Would I not leape vpright.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Let goe my hand,
Here friend's another pursse, in it a iewell,
Well worth a poore mans taking, Fairies and Gods
Prosper it with thee, goe thou farther off,
Bid me farewell, and let me heare thee going.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Now fare you well good sir.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why I do trifell thus with his dispaire is done to cure it.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: O you mightie Gods,
This world I doe renounce and in your sights
Shake patiently my great affliction off,
If I could beare it longer and not fall
To quarel with your great opposles wils
My snursf and loathed part of nature should
Burne it selfe out, if Edgar liue, O blesse,
Now fellow fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Gon sir, farewell, and yet I know not how conceit my robbe the treasurie of life, when life it selfe yealds to the theft, had he beene where he thought by this had thought beene past, aliue or dead, ho you sir, heare you sir, speak, thus might he passe indeed, yet he reuiues, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Away and let me die.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Hadst thou beene ought but gosmore feathers ayre,
So many fadome downe precipitating
Thou hadst shiuerd like an egge, but thou dost breath
Hast heauy substance, bleedst not, speakest, art sound,
Ten masts at each, make not the altitude,
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell,
Thy lifes a miracle, speake yet againe.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: But haue I fallen or no I

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: From the dread sommons of this chalkie borne,
Looke vp a hight, the shrill gorg'd larke so farre
Cannot bee seene or heard, doe but looke vp?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Alack I haue no eyes
Is wretchednes depriu'd, that benefit
To end it selfe by death twas yet some comfort
When misery could beguile the tyrants rage
And frustrate his proud will.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Giue me your arme?
Vp, so, how feele you your legges, you stand.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Too well, too well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: This is aboue all strangenes
Vpon the crowne of the cliffe what thing was that
Which parted from you.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: A poore vnfortunate bagger.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: As I stood here below me thoughts his eyes
Were two full Moones, a had a thousand noses
Hornes, welk't and waued like the enridged sea,
It was some fiend, therefore thou happy father
Thinke that the cleerest Gods, who made their honours
Of mens impossibilities, haue preserued thee.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: I doe remember now henceforth ile beare
Affliction till it doe crie out it selfe
Enough, enough and die that thing you speake of,
I tooke it for a man, often would it say
The fiend the fiend, he led me to that place

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bare free & patient thoughts, but who comes here
The safer sence will neare accommodate his maister thus.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No they cannot touch mee for coyning, I am the king himselfe.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O thou side pearcing sight.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Nature is aboue Art in that respect, ther's your presse money, that fellow handles his bow like a crow-keeper, draw me a clothiers yard, looke, looke a mowse, peace, peace, this tosted cheese will do it ther's my gauntlet, ile proue it on a gyant, bring vp the browne-billes, O well flowne bird in the ayre, hagh, giue the word?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sweet Margerum.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Passe.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: I know that voyce.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Ha Gonorill, ha Regan, they flattered mee like a dogge, and tould me I had white haires in my beard, ere the black ones were there, to say I and no, to euery thing I saide, I and no toe, was no good diuinitie, when the raine came to wet me once, and the winde to make mee chatter, when the thunder would not peace at my bidding, there I found them, there I smelt them out, goe toe, they are not men of their words, they told mee I was euery thing, tis a lye, I am not argue-proofe.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: The tricke of that voyce I doe well remember, ist not the King?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
I euer inch a King when I do stare▪ see how the subiect quakes, I pardon that mans life, what was thy cause, adultery? thou shalt not die for adulterie, no the wren goes toot, and the smal guilded flie doe letcher in my sight, let copulation thriue, for Glosters bastard son was kinder to his father then my daughters got tweene the lawfull sheets, toot luxurie, pell, mell, for I lacke souldiers, behold yon simpring dame whose face between her forkes presageth snow, that minces vertue, and do shake the head heare of pleasures name to fichew nor the soyled horse goes toot with a more riotous appetite, down from the wast tha're centaures, though women all aboue, but to the girdle doe the gods inherit, beneath is all the fiends, thers hell, thers darknesse, ther's the sulphury pit, burning, scalding, stench, consumation,
fie, fie, fie, pah, pah, Giue mee an ounce of Ciuet, good Apothocarie, to sweeten my imagination, ther's money for thee.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: O let me kisse that hand.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Here wipe it first, it smels of mortalitie.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: O ruind peece of nature, this great world should so ●●are out to naught, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: I remember thy eyes well inough, dost thou squiny on me, no do thy worst blind Cupid, ile not loue, reade thou that challenge, marke the penning oft.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Were all the letters sunnes I could not see one.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: I would not take this from report, it is, and my heart breakes at it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Read.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: What! with the case of eyes

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: O ho, are you there with me, no eyes in your head, nor no mony in your purse, your eyes are in a heauie case, your purse in a light, yet you see how this world goes.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: I see it feelingly.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What art mad, a man may see how the world goes with no eyes, looke with thy eares, see how you Iustice railes vpon you simple theefe, harke in thy eare handy, dandy, which is the theefe, which is the Iustice, thou hast seene a farmers dogge barke at a begger.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: And the creature runne from the cur, there thou mightst behold the great image of authoritie, a dogge, so bade in office, thou rascall beadle hold thy bloudy hand, why dost thou lash that whore, strip thine owne backe, thy bloud hotly lusts to vse her in that kind for which thou whipst her, the vsurer hangs the cosioner, through tottered raggs, smal vices do appeare, robes & furd-gownes hides all, get thee glasse eyes, and like a scuruy polititian seeme to see the things thou doest not, no now pull off my bootes, harder, harder, so.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: O matter and impertinencie mixt reason in madnesse.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: If thou wilt weepe my fortune take my eyes, I knowe thee well inough thy name is Gloster, thou must be patient, we came crying hither, thou knowest the first time that we smell the aire, we wayland cry I will preach to thee marke me.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.p: Alack alack the day.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
When we are borne, we crie that wee are come to this great stage of fooles, this a good blocke. It were a delicate stratagem
to shoot a troupe of horse with fell, & when I haue stole vpon these sonne in lawes, then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: O here he is, lay hands vpon him sirs, your most deere

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: No reskue, what a prisoner, I am eene the naturall foole of Fortune, vse me well you shall haue ransome, let mee haue a churgion I am cut to the braines.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You shall haue any thing.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: No seconds, all my selfe, why this would make a man of salt to vse his eyes for garden waterpots, I and laying Autums dust.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: I will die brauely like a bridegroome, what? I will be Iouiall, come, come, I am a King my maisters, know you that.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You are a royall one, and we obey you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Then theres life int, nay and you get it you shall get it with running.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A sight most pitifull in the meanest wretch, past speaking of in a king: thou hast one daughter who redeemes nature from the generall curse which twaine hath brought her to.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Haile gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir speed you, whats your will.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Do you heare ought of a battell toward.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Most sure and vulgar euery one here's that
That can distinguish sence.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: But by your fauour how neers the other army.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Neere and on speed fort the maine descryes,
Standst on the howerly thoughts.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thanke you sir thats all.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Though that the Queene on speciall cause is here,
Hir army is moued on.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: You euer gentle gods take my breath from me,
Let not my worser spirit tempt me againe,
To dye before you please.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Well, pray you father.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Now good sir what are you.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: A most poore man made lame by Fortunes blowes,
Who by the Art of knowne and feeling sorrowes
Am pregnant to good pitty, giue me your hand
Ile leade you to some biding.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Hartie thankes, the bornet and beniz of heauen to saue thee.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: A proclamed prize, most happy, that eyles head of thine was framed flesh to rayse my fortunes, thou most vnhappy traytor, briefly thy selfe remember, the sword is out that must destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Now let thy friendly hand put strength enough to't.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Wherefore bould pesant durst thou support a publisht traytor, hence least the infection of his fortune take like hold on thee, let goe his arme?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Ihill not let goe fir without cagion.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Let goe slaue, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Good Gentleman goe your gate, let poore voke passe, and Ihud haue beene swaggar'd out of my life, it would not haue beene so long by a fortnight, nay come not neare the old man, keepe out, cheuore ye, or ile trie whether your coster or my battero be the harder, ile be plaine with you.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Out dunghill.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Ihill pick your teeth sir, come, no matter for your foyns.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: Slaue thou hast slaine me, villaine take my pursse,
If euer thou wilt thriue, burie my bodie,
And giue the letters which thou find'st about me
To Edmund Earle of Gloster, seeke him out vpon
The British partie, ô vntimely death! death.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I know thee well, a seruiceable villaine,
As dutious to the vices of thy mistres, as badnes would desire.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What is he dead?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sit you down father, rest you lets see his pockets
These letters that he speakes of may be my friends,
Hee's dead, I am only sorrow he had no other deathsman
Let vs see, leaue gentle waxe, and manners blame vs not
To know our enemies minds wee'd rip their hearts,
Their papers is more lawfull.

Let your reciprocall vowes bee remembred, you haue many opportunities to cut him off, if your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered, there is nothing done, If he returne the conquerour, then am I the prisoner, and his bed my gayle, from the lothed warmth whereof deliuer me, and supply the place for
your labour, your wife (so I would say) your affectionate seruant and for you her owne for Venter, Gonorill.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O Indistinguisht space of womans wit,
A plot vpon her vertuous husbands life.
And the exchange my brother heere in the sands,
Thee ile rake vp, the post vnsanctified
Of murtherous leachers, and in the mature time,
With this vngratious paper strike the sight
Of the death practis'd Duke, for him tis well,
That of thy death and businesse I can tell.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: The King is mad, how stiffe is my vild sence,
That I stand vp and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorowes, better I were distract,
So should my thoughts be fenced from my griefes,
And woes by wrong imaginations loose
The knowledge of themselues.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Giue me your hand far off me thinks I heare the beaten drum,
Come father ile bestow you with a friend. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O thou good Kent how shall I liue and worke to match thy goodnes,
My life will be too short and euery measure faile me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: To be acknowlegd madame is ore payd,
All my reports go with the modest truth,
Nor more, nor clipt, but so.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Be better suited these weeds are memories of those
Worser howers, I prithe put them off.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Pardon me deere madame,
Yet to be knowne shortens my made intent,
My boone I make it that you know me not,
Till time and I thinke meete.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Then beet so, my good Lord how does the king.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madame sleepes still.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O you kind Gods cure this great breach in his abused nature,
The vntund and hurrying sences, O wind vp
Of this child changed father.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: So please your Maiestie that we may wake the king,
He hath slept long.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Be gouernd by your knowledge and proceed,
Ith sway of your owne will is he arayd,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I madam, in the heauinesse of his sleepe,
We put fresh garments on him,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good madam be by, when we do awake him
I doubt not of his temperance.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Please you draw neere, louder the musicke there,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O my deer father restoration hang thy medicin on my lips,
And let this kis repaire those violent harmes that my two sisters
Haue in thy reuerence made.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Klnd and deere Princesse,

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Had you not bene their father these white flakes,
Had challengd pitie of them, was this a face
To be exposd against the warring winds,
To stand against the deepe dread bolted thunder,
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick crosse lightning to watch poore Perdu,
With this thin helme mine iniurious dogge,
Though he had bit me, should haue stood that night
Against my fire, and wast thou faine poore father,
To houill thee with swine and rogues forlorne,
In short and mustie straw, alack, alack,
Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all, he wakes speake to him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madam do you, tis fittest.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: How does my royall Lord, how fares your maiestie.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You do me wrong to take me out ath graue,
Thou art a soule in blisse, but I am bound
Vpon a wheele of fire, that mine owne teares
Do scald like molten lead.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Sir know me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Yar a spirit I know, where did you dye.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Still, still, farre wide.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hees scarce awake, let him alone a while.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Where haue I bene, where am I faire day light,
I am mightily abusd, I should ene dye with pitie,
To see another thus, I know not what to say,
I will not sweare these are my hands, lets see,
I feele this pin pricke, would I were assur'd of my condition.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O looke vpon me sir, and hold your hands in benediction or'e me, no sir you must not kneele.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Pray doe not mocke,
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourescore and vpward, and to deale plainly
I feare I am not in my perfect mind,
Mee thinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtfull, for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is, and all the skill I haue
Remembers not these garments, nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night, doe not laugh at me,
For as I am a man, I thinke this Ladie
To be my child Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: And so I am.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Be your teares wet, yes faith, I pray weep not,
If you haue poyson for mee I will drinke it,
I know you doe not loue me, for your sisters
Haue as I doe remember, done me wrong,
You haue some cause, they haue not.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: No cause, no cause.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Am I in France?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: In your owne kingdome sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Doe not abuse me?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Be comforted good Madame, the great rage you see is cured in him, and yet it is danger to make him euen ore the time hee has lost, desire him to goe in, trouble him no more till further setling:

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Wilt please your highnes walke?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You must beare with me, pray now forget and forgiue,
I am old and foolish.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Holds it true sir that the Duke of Cornwall was so slaine?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Most certaine sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Who is conductor of his people?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: As tis said, the bastard sonne of Gloster.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They say Edgar his banisht sonne is with the Earle of Kent in Germanie.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Report is changeable, tis time to looke about,
The powers of the kingdome approach apace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The arbiterment is like to be bloudie, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My poynt and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well, or ill, as this dayes battels fought.
sp.stage: Enter Edmund, Regan, and their powers.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is aduis'd by ought
To change the course, he's full of abdication
And selfe reprouing, bring his constant pleasure.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our sisters man is certainly miscaried,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Tis to be doubted Madam,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Now sweet Lord,
You know the goodnes I intend vpon you,
Tell me but truly, but then speak the truth,
Doe you not loue my sister?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I, honor'd loue.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But haue you neuer found my brothers way,
To the forfended place?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: That thought abuses you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I am doubtfull that you haue beene coniunct and bosom'd with hir, as far as we call hirs.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: No by mine honour Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I neuer shall indure hir, deere my Lord bee not familiar with her.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Feare me not, shee and the Duke her husband.
sp.stage: Enter Albany and Gonorill with troupes.

sp.speaker: Gono.
sp.p: I had rather loose the battaile, then that sister should loosen him and mee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Our very louing sister well be-met
For this I heare the King is come to his daughter
With others, whome the rigour of our state
Forst to crie out, where I could not be honest
I neuer yet was valiant, for this busines
It touches vs, as France inuades our land
Not bolds the King, with others whome I feare,
Most iust and heauy causes make oppose.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sir you speake nobly.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why is this reason'd!

sp.speaker: Gono.
sp.l: Combine togither gainst the enemy,
For these domestique dore particulars
Are not to question here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let vs then determine with the auntient of warre on our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I shall attend you presently at your tent.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sister you'l goe with vs?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Tis most conuenient, pray you goe with vs.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O ho, I know the riddle, I will goe.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: If ere your Grace had speech with man so poore,
Heare me one word.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ile ouertake you, speake.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Before you fight the battell ope this letter,
If you haue victory let the trumpet sound
For him that brought it, wretched though I seeme,
I can produce a champion that will proue
What is auowched there, if you miscary,
Your busines of the world hath so an end,
Fortune loue you,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay till I haue read the letter.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I was forbid it, when time shall serue let but the Herald cry and ile appeare againe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why fare thee well, I will ore-looke the paper.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: The enemies in vew, draw vp your powers
Hard is the quesse of their great strength and forces
By diligent discouery, but your hast is now vrg'd on you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Wee will greet the time.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: To both these sister haue I sworne my loue,
Each iealous of the other as the sting are of the Adder,
Which of them shall I take, both one or neither, neither can bee inioy'd
If both remaine aliue, to take the widdow
Exasperates, makes mad her sister Gonorill,
And hardly shall I cary out my side
Her husband being aliue, now then we'le vse
His countenadce for the battaile, which being done
Let her that would be rid of him deuise
His speedie taking off, as for his mercy
Which he entends to Lear and to Cordelia:
The battaile done, and they within our power
Shall neuer see his pardon, for my state
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.
sp.stage: Alarum. Enter the powers of France ouer the stage, Cordelia with her father in her hand. Enter Edgar and Gloster.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here father, take the shaddow of this bush
For your good hoast, pray that the right may thriue
If euer I returne to you againe ile bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Grace goe with you sir.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Away old man, giue me thy hand, away,
King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter taine,
Giue me thy hand, come on.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: No farther sir, a man may rot euen here.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What in ill thoughts againe men must indure,
Their going hence, euen as their coming hither,
Ripenes is all come on.
sp.stage: Enter Edmund, with Lear and Cordelia prisoners.

sp.speaker: Bast,
sp.l: Some officers take them away, good guard
Vntill their greater pleasures best be knowne
That are to censure them.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: We are not the first who with best meaning haue incurd
The worst, for thee oppressed King am I cast downe,
My selfe could else outfrowne false Fortunes frowne,
Shall we not see these daughters, and these sisters?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No, no, come lets away to prison
We two alone will sing like birds it'h cage,
When thou dost aske me blessing, ile kneele downe
And aske of thee forgiuenes, so weele liue
And pray, and sing and tell old tales and laugh
At guilded butterflies, and heare poore rogues
Talke of Court newes, and weele talke with them to,
Who looses, and who wins, whose in, whose out,
And take vpon's the mistery of things
As if we were Gods spies, and weele weare out
In a wal'd prison, packs and sects of great ones
That ebbe and flow byth' Moone.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Take them away.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Vpon such sacrifices my Cordelia,
The Gods themselues throw incense, haue I caught thee?
He that parts vs shall bring a brand from heauen,
And fire vs hence like Foxes, wipe thine eyes,
The good shall deuoure em, fleach and fell
Ere they shall make vs weepe? wele see vm starue first, come.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Come hither Captaine, harke.
Take thou this note, goe follow them to prison,
And step, I haue aduanct thee, if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To noble fortunes, know thou this that men
Are as the time is, to be tender minded
Does not become a sword, thy great imployment
Will not beare question, either say thout do't,
Or thriue by other meanes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ile do't my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: About it, and write happy when thou hast don,
Marke I say instantly, and carie it so
As I haue set it downe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I cannot draw a cart, nor eate dride oats,
If it bee mans worke Ile do't.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, the two Ladies, and others.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir you haue shewed to day your valiant strain,
And Fortune led you well you haue the captiues
That were the opposites of this dayes strife,
We doe require then of you, so to vse them,
As we shall find their merits, and our safty
May equally determine.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sir I thought it fit,
To saue the old and miserable King to some retention,
Whose age has charmes in it, whose title more
To pluck the coren bossom of his fide,
And turne our imprest launces in our eyes
Which doe commaund them, with him I sent the queen
My reason, all the same and they are readie to morrow,
Or at further space, to appeare where you shall hold
Your session at this time, mee sweat and bleed,
The friend hath lost his friend and the best quarrels
In the heat are curst, by those that feele their sharpes,
The question of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir by your patience,
I hold you but a subiect of this warre, not as a brother.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: That's as we list to grace him,
Me thinkes our pleasure should haue beene demanded
Ere you had spoke so farre, he led our powers,
Bore the commission of my place and person,
The which imediate may well stand vp,
And call it selfe your brother.

sp.speaker: Gono.
sp.l: Not so hot, in his owne grace hee doth exalt himselfe more then in your aduancement.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: In my right by me inuested he com-peers the best.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: That were the most, if hee should husband you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Iesters doe oft proue Prophets.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Hola, hola, that eye that told you so, lookt but a squint.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lady I am not well, els I should answere
From a full flowing stomack, Generall
Take thou my souldiers, prisoners, patrimonie,
Witnes the world that I create thee here
My Lord and maister.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Meane you to inioy him then?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The let alone lies not in your good will.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Nor in thine Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Halfe blouded fellow, yes.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Let the drum strike, and proue my title good.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay yet, heare reason, Edmund I arrest thee
On capitall treason, and in thine attaint,
This gilded Serpent, for your claime faire sister
I bare it in the interest of my wife,
Tis she is subcontracted to this Lord
And I her husband contradict the banes,
If you will mary, make your loue to me,
My Lady is bespoke, thou art arm'd Gloster,
If none appeare to proue vpon thy head,
Thy hainous, manifest, and many treasons,
There is my pledge, ile proue it on thy heart
Ere I tast bread, thou art in nothing lesse
Then I haue here proclaimd thee.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sicke, ô sicke.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: If not, ile ne're trust poyson.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Ther's my exchange, what in the world he is,
That names me traytor, villain-like he lies,
Call by thy trumpet, he that dares approach,
On him, on you, who not, I will maintaine
My truth and honour firmely.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A Herald ho.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: A Herald ho, a Herald.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Trust to thy single vertue, for thy souldiers
All leuied in my name, haue in my name tooke their discharge.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: This sicknes growes vpon me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: She is not well, conuey her to my tent,
Come hether Herald, let the trumpet sound,
And read out this.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sound trumpet?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: If any man of qualitie or degree, in the hoast of the army, will maintaine vpon Edmund supposed Earle of Gloster, that he's a manifold traitour, let him appeare at the third sound of the trumpet, he is bold in his defence.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sound? Againe?
sp.stage: Enter Edgar at the third sound, a trumpet before him.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Aske him his purposes why he appeares
Vpon this call oth' trumpet.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What are you? your name and qualitie?
And why you answere this present summons.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O know my name is lost by treasons tooth.
Bare-gnawne and canker-bitte; yet are I mou't
Where is the aduersarie I come to cope with all.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Which is that aduersarie?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What's he that speakes for Edmund Earle of Gloster,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Him selfe, what saiest thou to him?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Draw thy sword.
That if my speech offend a noble hart, thy arme
May do thee Iustice, here is mine.
Behold it is the priuiledge of my tongue,
My oath and my profession, I protest,
Maugure thy strength, youth, place and eminence,
Despight thy victor, sword and fire new fortun'd,
Thy valor and thy heart thou art a traytor.
False to thy Gods thy brother and thy Father,
Conspicuate gainst this high illustrious prince,
And from the'xtreamest vpward of thy head,
To the descent and dust beneath thy feet,
A most toad-spotted traytor say thou no
This sword, this arme, and my best spirits,
As bent to proue vpon thy heart whereto I speake thou liest,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: In wisdome I sholud aske thy name,
But since thy outside lookes so faire and warlike,
And that thy being some say of breeding breathes,
By right of knighthood, I disdaine and spurne
Heere do I tosse those treasons to thy head.
With the hell hatedly, oreturnd thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by and scarcely bruse,
This sword of mine shall giue them instant way
Where they shall rest for euer, trumpets speake.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Saue him, saue him,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: This is meere practise Gloster by the law of armes
Thou art not bound to answere an vnknowne opposite,
Thou art not vanquisht, but cousned and beguild,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Stop your mouth dame, or with this paper shall I stople it, thou worse then any thing, reade thine owne euill, nay no tearing Lady, I perceiue you know't.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Say if I do, the lawes are mine not thine, who shal arraine me for't.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Most monstrous know'st thou this paper?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Aske me not what I know.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Go after her, shee's desperate, gouerne her.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: What you haue chargd me with, that haue I don
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
Tis past, and so am I, but what art thou
That hast this fortune on me? if thou bee'st noble
I do forgiue thee.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Let's exchange charity,
I am no lesse in bloud then thou art Edmund,
If more, the more thou hast wrongd me.
My name is Edgar, and thy fathers sonne,
The Gods are iust, and of our pleasant vertues.
Make instruments to scourge vs the darke and vitious
Place where thee he gotte, cost him his eies.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Thou hast spoken truth, the wheele is come full circled I am heere.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Me thought thy very gate did prophecie,
A royall noblenesse I must embrace thee.
Let sorow split my heart if I did euer hate thee or thy father.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Worthy Prince I know't.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where haue you hid your selfe?
How haue you knowne the miseries of your father?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: By nursing them my Lord,
List a briefe tale, and when tis told
O that my heart would burst the bloudy proclamation
To escape that followed me so neere,
O our liues sweetnes, that with the paine of death,
Would hourly die, rather then die at once.
Taught me to shift into a mad-mans rags
To assume a semblance that very dogges disdain'd
And in this habit met I my father with his bleeding rings,
The precious stones new lost became his guide,
Led him, beg'd for him, sau'd him from dispaire,
Neuer (O Father) reueald my selfe vnto him.
Vntill some halfe houre past, when I was armed,
Not sure, though hoping of this good successe,
I askt his blessing, and from first to last,
Told him my pilgrimage, but his flawd heart,
Alacke too weake, the conflict to support,
Twixt two extreames of passion, ioy and griefe,
Burst smillingly.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: This speech of yours hath moued me,
And shall perchance do good, but speake you on,
You looke as you had something more to say,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If there be more, more wofull, hold it in,
For I am almost ready to dissolue, hearing of this,

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: This would haue seemd a periode to such
As loue not sorow, but another to amplifie too much,
Would make much more, and top extreamitie
Whil'st I was big in clamor, came there in a man,
Who hauing seene me in my worst estate,
Shund my abhord society, but then finding
Who twas that so indur'd with his strong armes
He fastened on my necke and bellowed out,
As hee'd burst heauen, threw me on my father,
Told the most pitious tale of Lear and him,
That euer eare receiued, which in recounting
His griefe grew puissant and the strings of life,
Began to cracke twice▪ then the trumpets sounded.
And there I left him traunst.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But who was this.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Kent sir, the banisht Kent, who in diguise,
Followed his enemie king and did him seruice
Improper for a slaue.
sp.stage: Enter one with a bloudie knife,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What kind of helpe, what meanes that bloudy knife?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Its hot it smokes, it came euen from the heart of▪

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who man, speake?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your Lady sir, your Lady, and her sister
By her is poysoned, she hath confest it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I was contracted to them both, all three
Now marie in an instant.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Produce their bodies, be they aliue or dead,
This Iustice of the heauens that makes vs tremble,
Touches vs not with pity.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here comes Kent sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O tis he, the time will not allow
The complement that very manners vrges.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I am come to bid my King and maister ay good night,
Is he not here?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Great thing of vs forgot,
Speake Edmund, whers the king, and whers Cordelia
Seest thou this obiect Kent.
sp.stage: The bodies of Gonorill and Regan are brought in.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Alack why thus.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Yet Edmund was beloued,
The one the other poysoned for my sake,
And after slue her selfe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Euen so, couer their faces.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I pant for life, some good I meane to do,
Despight of my owne nature, quickly send,
Be briefe, int toth' castle for my writ,
Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia,
Nay send in time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Runne, runne, O runne.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: To who my Lord, who hath the office, send
Thy token of repreeue.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Well thought on, take my sword the Captaine,
Giue it the Captaine?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hast thee for thy life.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: He hath Commission from thy wife and me,
To hang Cordelia in the prison, and to lay
The blame vpon her owne despaire,
That she fordid her selfe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The Gods defend her, beare him hence a while.
sp.stage: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Howle, howle, howle, howle, O you are men of stones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, I would vse them so,
That heauens vault should cracke, shees gone for euer,
I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
Shees dead as earth, lend me a looking glasse,
If that her breath will mist or staine the stone,
Why then she liues.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Is this the promist end.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Or image of that horror.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fall and cease.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This feather stirs she liues, if it be so,
It is a chance which do's redeeme all sorowes
That euer I haue felt.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: A my good maister.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prethe away?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Tis noble Kent your friend.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A plague vpon your murderous traytors all,
I might haue saued her, now shees gone for euer,
Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little, ha,
What ist thou sayest, her voyce was euer soft,
Gentle and low, an excellent thing in women,
I kild the slaue that was a hanging thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Tis true my Lords, he did.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Did I not fellow? I haue seene the day,
With my good biting Fauchon I would
Haue made them skippe, I am old now,
And these same crosses spoyle me, who are you?
Mine eyes are not othe best, ile tell you straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: If Fortune bragd of two she loued or hated,
One of them we behold.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Are not you Kent?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The same your seruant Kent, where is your seruant Caius,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Hees a good fellow, I can tell that,
Heele strike and quickly too, hees dead and rotten.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No my good Lord, I am the very man.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ile see that straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: That from your life of difference and decay,
Haue followed your sad steps.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You'r welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Nor no man else, als chearles, darke and deadly,
Your eldest daughters haue foredoome themselues.
And desperatly are dead.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So thinke I to.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He knowes not what he sees, and vaine it is,
That we present vs to him.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Very bootlesse.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Edmund is dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thats but a trifle heere, you Lords and noble friends, Know our intent, what comfort to this decay may come, shall be applied: for vs we wil resigne during the life of this old maiesty, to him our absolute power, you to your rights with boote, and such addition as your honor haue more then merited, all friends shall tast the wages of their vertue, and al foes the cup of their deseruings, O see, see.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: And my poore foole is hangd, no, no life, why should a dog, a horse, a rat of life and thou no breath at all, O thou wilt come no more, neuer, neuer, neuer, pray you vndo this button, thanke you sir, O, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: He faints my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Breake hart, I prethe breake.

sp.speaker: Edgar.
sp.l: Look vp my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Vex not his ghost, O let him passe,
He hates him that would vpon the wracke,
Of this tough world stretch him out longer.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O he is gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The wonder is, he hath endured so long,
He but vsurpt his life.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Beare them from hence, our present busines
Is to generall woe, friends of my soule, you twaine
Rule in this kingdome, and the goard state sustaine.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I haue a iourney sir, shortly to go,
My maister cals, and I must not say no.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The waight of this sad time we must obey,
Speake what we feele, not what we ought to say,
The oldest haue borne most, we that are yong,
Shall neuer see so much, nor liue so long.
